plants.name: Rhododendron ponticum
plants.description: An evergreen shrub native to southern Europe and southwest Asia, known for its large clusters of bell-shaped flowers that range from purple to pink hues. It thrives in temperate regions and is often found in woodland and heathland.
plants.funFact: The nectar of Rhododendron flowers contains grayanotoxins, which can be toxic to humans and animals if ingested.

plants.name: Tibouchina urvilleana
plants.description: A tropical evergreen shrub native to Brazil with vibrant purple, velvety flowers and striking deep green leaves. Often grown in subtropical and warm temperate gardens worldwide.
plants.location: Brazil, cultivated in subtropical regions worldwide
plants.funFact: Princess Flower attracts a variety of pollinators, including bees and butterflies, making it popular for garden biodiversity.

plants.name: Lupinus perennis
plants.description: A North American native perennial wildflower with tall spikes adorned with pea-like flowers, typically in shades of blue, purple, or white. It grows well in sandy soils and open woods.
plants.funFact: Wild Lupine is an important larval host plant for the endangered Karner Blue butterfly.

plants.name: Echinacea purpurea
plants.description: A hardy perennial native to North America, recognized by its large purple-pink daisy-like flowers with a spiny central cone. It is widely cultivated for its medicinal properties and attractiveness to pollinators.
plants.funFact: Echinacea is used traditionally to boost the immune system and is popular in herbal remedies.
